Welcome to PKPy’s documentation!¶

PKPy is a small Python package to solve simple, compartment-based pharmacokinetic models. It currently supports bolus (one-time) or continuous drug administration and an arbitrary number of peripheral compartments. Drugs can be administered directly into a central compartment, or alternatively flow first into a special subcutaneous compartment and thence into the central one.

See the full documentation in the docs/ directory.

Installation¶

After cloning PKPy, you can use pip to install it:

pip install /path/to/PKPy

Usage¶

Specify your Model¶

Specify all parameters of the model to be solved in a JSON configuration file, with the following structure:

{
    "basic_parameters" : {
        "time_span": 10000,
        "subcutaneous" : 1,
        "dose" : [10,"continuous"]
    },

    "compartment_1" : {
        "name" : "Bloodstream",
        "type" : "central",
        "volume" : 5000,
        "initial_amount" : 0.0,
        "rate_out": 10
    },

    "compartment_3" : {
        "name" : "Liver",
        "type" : "peripheral",
        "volume" : 2000,
        "initial_amount" : 0.0,
        "rate_in" : 1.0,
        "rate_out": 0.5
    },

    "compartment_4" : {
        "name" : "Subcutaneous",
        "type" : "subcutaneous",
        "volume" : 3000,
        "initial_amount" : 0.0,
        "rate_in" : 1.0,
        "rate_out": 0.1
    }
    ...
}

Compartment names may be freely chosen, but their type must be one of "central", "subcutaneous" and "peripheral". If a "subcutaneous"-type compartment is present, the boolean flag "subcutaneous" must be set to 1, otherwise, it must be set to 0.

The "dose" parameter specifies the administration protocol. Specify a numeric dosage amount followed by one of "continuous" (for constant administration) or "bolus" (for one-time administration at time 0) as a list. Alternatively, specify a custom dosage protocol as an arbitrary expression containing ‘x’ (the time variable) as a string. Refer to any numpy functions as np.. For example:

"basic_parameters" : {
        "subcutaneous" : 1,
        "dose" : "np.sin(x) + 100"
    }

See the examples/ folder for inspiration.

Usage from Python¶

After specifying the model parameters in a json configuration as described above, use the package from Python, like so:

import PKPy as pk

model = pk.Model('/path/to/model_paramters.json') # initialise model from json
solution_timeseries = model.solve() # solve model
model.plot() # plot the results

This will generate a plot of individual compartment concentrations over time. Individual time-series can then be accessed as solution_timeseries['compartment_name'] for further analysis.

License PKPy is released under the MIT License. See LICENSE for details.

Documentation of Classes and Functions¶

class PKPy.model.Compartment(dict)¶

A class representing a compartment in a pharmacokinetic model.

Variables:

  • name (str) – The name of the compartment.

  • type (str) – The type of the compartment (‘central’, ‘subcutaneous’, or ‘peripheral’).

  • volume (float) – The volume of the compartment.

  • initial_amount (float) – The initial amount of substance in the compartment.

  • rate_in (float) – The rate of substance flowing into the compartment.

  • rate_out (float) – The rate of substance flowing out of the compartment.

class PKPy.model.Model(systemfile)¶

A class representing a pharmacokinetic model.

Variables:

  • systemfile (str) – The name of the system file (compartment definitions).

  • is_subcutaneous (bool) – Whether the model has a subcutaneous compartment or not.

  • dose_type (str) – The type dosage schedule (‘bolus’ or ‘continuous’) or user-provided dosage function.

  • dose_constant (float) – The dose constant (defaults to 10 if user provides a dosage function).

  • compartment_list (list) – A list of compartments in the model (as Compartment objects).

  • central (Compartment) – The central compartment.

  • subcutaneous (Compartment) – The subcutaneous compartment (if present).

  • other_compartments (list) – A list of other (peripheral) compartments (as Compartment objects) in the model.

Usage Example:

>>> model = Model('system.json')
>>> model.solve()
>>> model.plot()    # outputs a plot of the model to results/
dose(t)¶

Returns the dose at time t using dosage function specified by the user in the system config file. The options are:

Parameters:

t (float) – The time at which to calculate the dose.

Returns:

The dose at time t.

Return type:

float

ode_system(t, y)¶

The system of ordinary differential equations (ODEs) that describe the model.

Parameters:

  • t (float) – The current time.

  • y (list) – A list of the current amounts of substance in each compartment. The order of the compartments is as follows: central, peripheral (any number), subcutaneous (if present).

Returns:

A list of the derivatives of the amounts of substance in each compartment in the same order as the input y.

Return type:

list

plot(title='PK Model', zoom_start=0, zoom_end=100, output='pk_model.png')¶

Plots the ODE solutions over time. Requires Model.solve() to be run first.

Parameters:

  • title (str) – Title of the plot. Default is ‘PK Model’.

  • zoom_start (int) – Starting timestep for the zoomed in plot. Default is 0.

  • zoom_end (int) – Ending timestep for the zoomed in plot. Default is 100.

  • output (str) – Output file name for the plot. Default is ‘pk_model.png’.

Raises:

ValueError – If no timeseries data is found, or if the pickle file is not a dictionary.

Usage Example:

>>> model = Model('system.json')
>>> model.solve()
>>> model.plot()   # outputs a plot of the model to results/
solve()¶

Solves the system of ODEs using scipy.integrate.solve_ivp, returns the solutions, and also writes them out to a pickle file in the results/ directory.

Returns:

A dictionary containing the timeseries for each compartment.

Return type:

dict

class PKPy.system_parser.Parser(system_config)¶

This class parses and stores the system configuration from a user-provided config file in JSON (compartment definitions).

Parameters:

system_config (str) – The path to the system configuration file (compartment definitions).

Usage Example:

>>> parser = Parser('system.json')
>>> parser.construct()
[{'subcutaneous': 1, 'dose': [100, 'bolus']}, [{'name': 'Central', 'type': 'central', 'volume': 2, 'initial_amount': 0, 'rate_in': 0, 'rate_out': 0}, {'name': 'Peripheral', 'type': 'peripheral', 'volume': 1, 'initial_amount': 0, 'rate_in': 0, 'rate_out': 0}, {'name': 'Subcutaneous', 'type': 'subcutaneous', 'volume': 0.5, 'initial_amount': 0, 'rate_in': 0, 'rate_out': 0}]]
construct()¶

For an initialised Parser object, constructs and returns the system configuration.

Returns:

A list, containing the model’s basic parameters (as a dictionary) and individual compartment parameters (as a list of dictionaries).

Return type:

list

Raises:

  • ValueError – If the subcutaneous flag is set to True, the corresponding compartment must also be defined and vice versa.

  • ValueError – If drug dosage is not a positive number.

  • ValueError – If drug administration type is not ‘bolus’ or ‘continuous’.

  • ValueError – If there is not exactly one compartment with a ‘central’ type.

  • ValueError – If there is more than one compartment with a ‘subcutaneous’ type.

  • ValueError – If a compartment has a type other than ‘central’, ‘subcutaneous’, or ‘peripheral’.

  • ValueError – If the volume of a compartment is not a positive number.
